pros: Friendly, great facilities, incredible teaching.
cons: Small compared to other locations but it doesn’t hinder your education in any way.

job_title: Prefer To Remain Anonymous in London, England
pros: Opportunities for personal development in terms of training and courses. Diverse recruitment of staff with a good representation of women in leadership positions. Long-term operational objectives clearly communicated. Friendly colleagues.
cons: Conflicting priorities amongst academics and business professionals can stifle progress. Communication across departments could be better managed - often updates are provided at a management level but aren't relayed to operational staff. Salary increase not in line with inflation. Difficulty to progress - even when someone leaves the organisation, there's no guarantee that role will be advertised again. This is prevalent across many departments. During peak periods, the workload can become overwhelming. This could be better managed by employing seasonal workers but this doesn't appear to be an option across all departments.

job_title: Senior Business Professional in London, England
pros: My ideas are listened to . I feel valued in this respect and am shown consideration when flexibility is needed in my work. There is a fantastic culture of support and collaboration in my department.
cons: My salary is worth less and less with each passing year and I see no real way of maintaining its value through meaningful salary increase. This is demoralising.

pros: Great flexibility and relationship with colleagues.
cons: Continuous teaching throughout the year. Pay is pretty average.

job_title: Access and Participation Coordinator in London, England
pros: It was a good experience to gain.
cons: They could pay a bit more though,

review_title: Awful employer going down the pan - never again
job_title: Undisclosed for Privacy in London, England
pros: People are hard working and professional but they don’t last long. Find a good team you might be alright. If you have any problems you won’t be supported. Get out while you can.
cons: Awful place to work - terrible HR- don’t deal with any complaints effectively. Pale stale male management - profits over staff and students- lack of investment- under staffed - over worked. Transition into a university then get the hell out if you value your MH.

pros: Remote working Annual leave no of days
cons: Old systems Heavy processes Lack of learning

pros: Nice environment formal culture clean
cons: Not research focused too much attention on tier 4 students and home office Not very suitable for proper academics

review_title: Working at the University of Law
job_title: Student Information Hub Manager in Bristol, England
pros: Fair salary, good work life balance, good holiday allowance
cons: Centralised services, lack of communication from top management

job_title: Student Finance Officer in Guildford, England
pros: Some colleagues are nice & helpful. Good benefits
cons: This is not a finance role it's a customer services call centre role. You will be on the phone non stop. There's people within the team who think that they are management when they are not moaning that there's no one answering the phone. The abuse from students is disgusting & nothing is ever done about them. There's a clicky atmosphere

pros: The Uni recruits some good staff who are generally easy to work with. The benefits are OK but not great.
cons: The culture of the institution is something else. Secretive, Conservative (both small and big C), untransparent, men in suits in the backroom who you don't see steering the ship. Disappearing Vice-chancellors replaced by a puppet who had left permanently just a year before reemerging. Massive growth in student numbers set in a climate of austerity. Job cuts, freezing of posts, offshoring of posts to low wage destinations, travel budgets slashed. Nefarious, opaque, obscure.

job_title: Student Recruitment Officer in Chester, England
pros: Good company to work for
cons: Travel can be a lot at times

review_title: Horrible culture, avoid if you have any morals
pros: Ability to work from home
cons: The whole university is incredibly disorganised and nothing works as it should. There is a large blame culture from senior management (VC and Provost) and it's very clear that their main priority is making as much money as possible. They don't care about staff or student experience and don't listen to staff concerns or expertise. Morally their business approach is horrendous and makes me so uncomfortable as an employee

job_title: Programme and Student Lead in London, England
pros: Strong support network, good quality of life.
cons: Too concerned about getting bums in seats.

review_title: Great Company to work for with its quirks
pros: Flexible Working; Generous Salary; Great People; Enthusiasm; Passion
cons: Silo working; transformation difficult to implement

review_title: Nice place to work but no progression
pros: Lovely working environment and team
cons: Low salaries and no progression

pros: good people determined to continuously improve the services we deliver - often in a challenging environment - but always mutually supportive
cons: multi-site - you need to be a good pro-active communicator and relationship builder

pros: Supportive Collaborative Intellectually stimulating Varied
cons: None None None None None

pros: They are very supportive of your career aspiration and wish to see you progress and will do anything they can do to help you
cons: Small facilities as it’s a small university

pros: Good pay structure Reliable management
cons: Unpredictable hardships Nothing else co es to my mind

pros: It is a renowned Institution
cons: I don't know yet as I only just started

review_title: Great team, amazing opportunties - really pleased to be part of the ULaw team!
job_title: Head of Ecommerce in Exeter, England
pros: Initially joined under a short term contract, didn't ever see a career with a University in my future path - but so happy to have stumbled into a company who invest into their staff, understand the importance of well-being (especially whilst working remotely), and highly encourage further development (I guess Uni's do practice what they preach!). ULaw is on a very special journey, and have to say the Marketing team I joined have been incredibly welcoming - a fun, but dedicated team who are happy to support their colleagues. I highly recommend applying to ULaw.
cons: Only negative so far has been joining a company under lockdown conditions and not being able to meet anyone in person - yet! But the same could be said for many new starters over the past 2 years.

pros: Colleagues are amazing, very professional and supportive.
cons:
Management is very poor. Not supportive/helpful. Little communication.
Workload is excessive and pay is poor.

pros:
Flexible working for some
Good office locations
cons:
Toxic culture with no gratitude and often quick to blame
No salary review or increase 
Staff perks limited
Communication is often confused 
A lot of internal progression based on friendships and not competence
Quite a few senior positions lack HE knowledge from sector 
Stripping on site resources for more cost effective remote workers

job_title: Careers and Employability Services in London, England
pros:
Plenty of opportunities to use your initiative and suggest solutions to challenges as they present themselves.
Very collaborative team environment
cons:
Team needs to grow to meet work demands
Salary could improve

review_title: A fast paced, exciting place to work
pros:
The university is rapidly changing and expanding, which makes it a really dynamic and exciting place to work.
If you have new ideas you’re given the ability to try new things and initiatives which is great and a welcome change from some other HEIs I’ve worked at.
It’s also a really friendly environment- I’ve got to know people across teams and campuses as well as my own so it has a real community feel.
cons:
Targets can be challenging.
Tutors get location weighting but ‘business professionals’ don’t, which doesn’t seem particularly fair, especially given the high cost of living in London/the South campuses

pros:
Lovely team, lots of training and support and just overall a great working environment. It's relaxed although challenging at times, but there is trust in employees which is highly motivating. 

Work is very varied, sometimes fast-pace and sometimes more relaxed, which is a nice balance.

Great benefits and holiday allowance too.
cons:
Sometimes difficulty communicating between teams due to high workloads, which can sometimes cause frustration in students too. 

Requires a lot of initiative so often you are just left to your own devices which might be overwhelming to those new to the world of work, but there is an abundance of support/training available.

Salary could be higher.

pros: Very friendly and relaxed employers - a great place to work.
cons: There aren't always many shifts available and sometimes, shifts are taken on a first come first serve basis.

pros: Great opportunities for progression and development, with lots of internal promotion and they paid for me to do a postgraduate qualification in my own time. Very committed to the student experience and to student centred learning, and staff do genuinely care about the students. Undergoing a rapid expansion with an increase in student numbers so good to see new colleagues joining regularly but there are also tutors who have been there for over 20 years so there is plenty of support from colleagues.
cons: There is a lot of marking.

job_title: Visa Requirements Officer in London, England
pros: The colleagues are super friendly and the work is not very difficiult.
cons: The deadlines can be stressful and overwhelming.

pros: Very supportive working environment. Generous annual leave. Work is varied and stimulating. Good opportunities for development and progression. Generous remuneration package. Genuine diversity and inclusion.
cons: Courses run all year - so unlike some other Universities there are not long student holiday periods and teaching goes on all year. Some marking platforms are unnecessarily complex.

pros: Good benefits, fair pay and a friendly, supportive culture.
cons: Mandatory requirement to work in the office.

pros: Good environment, Diverse, Great Flexibility
cons: There is no cons at this place.

pros:
1) The job is fun. All you have to do is share your experience with prospective students and answer their questions about the University or its courses. 
2) Easy job with a decent wage. 
3) Earn while you learn. 
4) No required amount you have to work. Work a shift as and when you're available.
5) Recruitment Staff are so helpful and friendly. If you can't make a shift they are super understanding but notify them in advance.
cons: Nothing. I have really enjoyed working as a Student Ambassador at The University of Law.

job_title: Professional Development Scheduling Executive in Guildford, England
pros: Great annual leave entitlement and bonus days
cons: Salary increase not given on performance

pros: Job I found during lockdown which has been a great job to have ensuring I had some money coming in during the last year.
cons: Its not work that I am passionate about and not a career role

review_title: Could of been a nice place to work
pros: small software house team, commutable, near town of guildford, nice people overall all around the building , other departments
cons: too many brown nosers, too many snakes and sharks, backbiting no moral support, no help

pros: Decent Pay and generous holiday. Seems like a nice Exec team
cons:
If you are an experienced EA this is not the role for you. You will be micro managed, patronised and your experiences will be ignored.

Senior EA is not open to suggestions and wants a assistant. 

Your almost treated like a child

pros: good life/work balance no pressure to do overtime, relatively easy job and good pay
cons: in less busy periods it can be boring as there is no task to do

review_title: Great part time work for law students
pros: You decide when to work, make good connections, gain brand ambassador experience
cons: A more challenging role to do online during the pandemic

pros: Good management; professional environment;good systems and tech
cons: Job becomes very busy and demanding during peak times

pros: Great staff, flexible, created safe space to ask about more training opportunities
cons: Worked during covid and it was under staffed

pros: Lovely students and helpful colleagues
cons: last minute scheduling and delivery of course materials

job_title: Testing Team Leader in Guildford, England
pros: Good working hours, flexibility, friendly
cons: Hampered by red tape at times

pros: very helpful and approachable tutors
cons: Not overly organised or good with communication

review_title: Lack of structure and volatile legal department
pros: Nice people who work there with a wealth of knowledge because they have been there for decades.
cons: No consistency in the legal department - I was there for 6 months and there was a change of GC 3 times!

pros: Great working environment, you feel valued as a member of staff
cons: Could have better staff facilities, i.e. staff kitchen is far to small and requires refurbishment

pros: Lovely people that work there
cons: Overworked, under appreciated, no progression

pros:
Very friendly team members met throughout the interview process
Warm welcome upon hiring
Very accessible onboarding/training process
Swift transitional period with the provision of equipment to get started
cons: The hiring process was a little longer than anticipated

pros: Good working culture and friendly colleagues
cons: Benefits could be more attractive

pros: Annual leave, and location of campuses.
cons: Hierarchical, controlling line managers, multiple it systems used that do not talk to each other. Covid19 planning was shambolic and put health at risk. No development.

pros: Friendly staff, relaxed atmosphere, adequate premises
cons: Work can be repetitive, career progression is very limited

pros: Friendly colleagues, opt in shifts, flexibility
cons: Inconvenient locations, high competition for hours

pros: Colleagues are lovely and are ever so helpful when you need a hand, the benefits are good and the location of the centres is great. The University takes great care in looking after their employees with many well-being sessions. There is always someone to help you or guide you so you are never alone.
cons: Some of the systems are quite old to use which can sometimes make a task more difficult than it should be. Unfortunately there are not many opportunities for progression within a role or department, however it is a fabulous place to progress and learn more about a fantastic company.

pros:
I have worked at the University for over a year now and no single day has ever been the same. 

The work is interesting, challenging and from my own professional perspective developmental. The people are nice and the pay and benefits package are competitive when compared to other HE providers. 

My line manager is very supportive and in my experience senior management are very approachable.
cons: I haven't experienced any particular downsides in my short time with the organisation.

pros: None whatsoever, none whatsoever, none.
cons:
The Glassdoor info is wrong. The current owner is NOT John Latham, but Arkady Etingen, a Russian 'self-made' billionaire investing in Private Equity who has bought and destroyed whatever was left of this  university.
managed by the Con party, which they fund.
Madness is un understatement. Chaotic, disorganised, rude, bullish.Students are treated like cash cows. Selling the entrepreneur dream to gullible young people.
 Students are taught politicised law, not law.  Anything to do with the EU is a no-no.. Students are bullied, and overcharged. I pity them. Nepotism rife throughout. Harassment between staff is the norm, including teaching staff. It's all treated like a joke.

pros:
The people (generally) are great and really committed to the development of the students and their professional qualifications.  The Board seem to be in a much better place than they were 18m ago and working together with more stability.  They are human - but it's also a two way process - we all need to make an effort to acknowledge each other. 

Managers are flexible with staff if this is reciprocated and the availability of training has increased dramatically over the last year or so.  Most people are very friendly and supportive of each other.
cons:
Some of the systems are not great and still need updating but the IT comms are good at keeping us informed of what they are doing.  

New intranet - at last!!!!  Unfortunately some people still can't be bothered to make an effort for themselves and go and look at it...... 

Some of the longer serving members of staff are still stuck in the past - 'why can't we have summers off......' really?! 'why do I have to come in when it's quiet......' really?! They need to understand we are a business and, like the rest of the world, have to change and adapt to keep up - or there will be no jobs! Have you tried doing something in those 'quiet times' (I've never had any) which is not just 'your job' and helping others?

If people are unhappy in their role (or any aspect of life) - change it! Don't try and depress your colleagues with your point of view - it's a big world out there, try it ;-)

pros:
Good pay and benefits, offering working flexibility.

Majority of staff are very friendly and good at collaborating on projects.

Opportunities to develop in your role and to really make a difference in the business.  It is not like other HE institutions but this is a positive, it is more commercial and understands what it is trying to achieve.
cons: As with any role there are challenges with lots of ambition and not always the resource or time to achieve them.

pros: Nice people, more down to earth at Store Street, few pretentious vibes at Moorgate, overall a good atmosphere, workload increased over recent years so people are more stressed
cons: Bit gossipy, used to have great xmas parties, now too tight to do much

job_title: Multi Skilled Operator in London, England
pros: I worked at the university for years and saw lots of changes but on the plus side, nice people, fairly stress free hours and workload
cons: in all those years it was abundantly clear that the management structure had little ideea of what it was doing and the management system that doesn't see a great opportunity and instead cuts its losses and runs

pros:
Good colleagues
Motivated students
Private healthcare
Reasonable salary
The work was worth doing
cons:
Terrible divisional management led to ridiculously petty and demoralising rules, e.g. a dress code
Terms and conditions were continuously eroded
Our division's successes were trumpeted in marketing materials, but the importance of our work was never recognised by new senior management

pros:
• HR were kind 
• Somewhat flexible start/finish hours
cons:
• Very desk based
• Very “us and them” between support/academics 
• Image conscious 
• lots of admin
• limited budgets 
• poor communication between departments 
• no London weighting for support staff 
• no value or appreciation of staff 
• Have to use A/L to take Christmas period off...

review_title: Supportive and exciting place to work
pros:
Departments work well together; supportive management;face-paced constantly changing environment;  generous leave and and great additional benefits
Supportive flexible working culture which leads to a good work life balance
Enjoy working working with all of my colleagues and enjoy the supportive nature of the team
cons: Internal communication regarding changes in the business could be improved; pace of changes means large volumes of work done at short notice; welcome and inductions could be improved for new hires to the organisation

pros: Generous holiday allowance of six weeks
cons:
The most shockingly incompetent, inept executive board I have had to work for.  The most dysfunctional organisation, which has a very high turn over rate of staff.

Staff treated as disposable commodities when they are unable to achieve the most basic tasks of their jobs due to the dysfunctional management style which sees senior management changing their minds about key business decisions on a weekly basis. 

No professional career progression opportunities whatsoever. 

AVOID. You will only end up burnt out and demoralised like the majority of staff who have either left or remain there.

pros:
Flexible working time.

Low , easy work load. 

You will probably never meet your manager as they're never on site for long.
cons:
Work is repetitive and non challenging
Low pay
Uneven pay better similar job roles fuels hostility between coworkers.
Poorly organised.
Very "Clicky". "newbies" and "scrubs" not welcome.
No progression opportunities 
No training provided
No work objectives set
No social life/perks/team building

job_title: National Head of Assessment Operations Delivery in London, England
pros: The people and management I worked with were largely supportive. I was grateful for educational sponsorship and support to complete a leadership & management degree at the Open University during my time at ULaw.
cons: The need to diversify aggressively given the proposed changes to legal education and assessment.

review_title: Great colleagues and business really moving forward
pros:
People are professional and friendly
Collegiate culture, not too much politics
cons: A lot of change, people are under a bit of pressure

job_title: Student Recruitment Officer in Bloomsbury, England
pros: Salary, annual leave, office location, opportunity to travel to events
cons: Very unsupportive working environment, minimal training before being sent to events on your own, cliquey teams which turn against you very quickly, HR department which so obviously cares about the bottom line over employee wellbeing, very secretive about developments within the team.

pros: Pay grades similar to leading universities
cons:
Unfair practices were rife across management and HR.
Poor decision making and forward planning.
Management had no clue what they were doing often making it up as they go along.
School ground atmosphere, bullyish behaviours from management.

pros: Supportive and empathetic culture (both students and staff). Well structured and well delivered lectures and workshops. Excellent careers and pro-bono service.
cons: Busy schedule with hard work (but rewarding)

pros: Nice people, good pension, fairly easy work
cons: Management visit centres and promise the world, nothing ever happens. Tick box exercise. Bullying of staff rife especially in Leeds. Good practice put into place but never observed.

pros: University invests in developing people and provides development oppurtunities
cons: Some senior staff have left and not been replaced leaving big gaps in teams.

pros:
Interesting learning about real cases. Office in good location. 
Great holiday allowance
cons: Pay is a pittance for central London. No progression within department.

job_title: Business Development Professional in Birmingham, England
pros: Opportunities, challenges, business growth, great people, flexible, work/life balance, benefits
cons: Processes, breaks, not as prestigious as it should be

pros: There are no pros at all
cons:
Bullying, back stabbing culture.  I didn't know work places could be as bad as this.
The most unprofessional environment. If they don't like you, watch out!

pros:
Good salary
Location in London easy to travel to

Little support given to those who don’t fit in straight away
Blame culture 
Overworking and overtime not only encouraged, but expected

pros: Friendly, self development, soft skills training
cons: Salary could be higher but excellent benefits

pros: Supportive management and colleagues

pros: Nothing terrible terrible culture
